summary: The House Assassinations Committee was a U.S. House of Representatives committee tasked with investigating the assassinations of President John F. Kennedy and Martin Luther King Jr. The documents provided indicate the committee's active role in seeking information from the NSA regarding potential foreign involvement, specifically focusing on Cuban communications and intelligence activities between 1959 and 1974. The committee sought intercepts related to reactions to the JFK assassination and potential assassination plots. The documents span from 1978 to 1979, reflecting the period when the committee was actively pursuing leads and requesting information from intelligence agencies.
significance: The House Assassinations Committee played a crucial role in investigating potential conspiracies and foreign involvement in the JFK assassination. Their inquiries to the NSA highlight the committee's efforts to explore all possible leads, including those related to Cuban intelligence and intercepted communications. The committee's work aimed to provide a comprehensive understanding of the circumstances surrounding President Kennedy's death.
